The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to designate a 23.5 mile segment of the Lamprey River in New Hampshire as a recreational river, administered by the Secretary of the Interior through cooperative agreements with the State of New Hampshire. The Lamprey River in New Hampshire, including towns like Epping, Lee, Durham, and Newmarket, will be managed according to the Lamprey River Management Plan, with amendments approved by the Secretary of the Interior. The Lamprey River in New Hampshire will be managed according to a comprehensive management plan under section 3(d). The Secretary of the Interior will coordinate management responsibilities with the Lamprey River Advisory Committee. Zoning ordinances in towns like Epping, Lee, Durham, and Newmarket will include provisions for conservation of shoreland, floodplains, and wetlands associated with the segment. The Secretary's authority to acquire land for the Lamprey River management plan is limited to donation or with owner consent, and must meet specific criteria to prevent federal acquisition by condemnation. The Lamprey River Management Plan requires specific criteria for land acquisition, with limitations on federal condemnation. Section 405 of the Omnibus Parks and Public Lands Management Act of 1996 is repealed.
